captions.text: izayoi99 asks
You guys have been on a diet right?
It looks like it's been going well for you two
How'd it go so well?
Any tips? I must know
:D
It was D:
It can't be a smiley face, the eyes are above and
if your mouth is like that
Yes we've been on a diet.
How long have been on it for now?
I think we've been on it since April
We've been doing a whole life change rather than just calling it as a diet
because diet usually entails like being something for a bit
As soon as you get your desired result, you stop doing it
but we are trying to change the way we eat and living altogether
The first thing we decided to do was really tough, cutting out all of our carbs
Now it might be a easy thing to do when you are living in North America
you can have really cool meals that are on the menu, like carb-free menu choices
But in Korea, everything is like white rice, white noodles
really really tough
Pretty much rice is starts off with every single meal
Every time when we went to a restaurant, we had to tell them that we don't want rice with our meal
They would look like us like crazy, and we would be like
"We're on a diet, we can't eat rice anymore"
"What do you mean??! Rice is healthy!! You should eat the rice"
"Rice is the Meal!!!"
"I can eat this Kimchijjigae with no rice "
of course we are talking this conversation with Korean
and it's hard to explain it to somebody
I think they would be less surprised, if we tied our hands and eat it with our faces
than rice altogether
People living in Korea, born and raised in Korea, eating rice is normal, healthy thing for them
But for us, considering we only had rice in Canada
Apparently never
Rice is like turing itself between the tighs in my ass
and my arm fat, muscles
"Is this your arm fat? I want to snuggle "
I'm like, "Don't do it rice, no......"
So that was our first step, cutting out the noodles and white rice
and all the yummy things that I like about Korea
Second step perhaps more difficult,
Cut out all the crap
and ate and drank lots and lots of crap
We would like to thank you for really nice fan mail package that you sent us
For all those delicious crap, but we ate all of it
Pretty much all the time and as a result we became a little bit rounder than usual
Yah, the biggest problem probably was that
we would be eating a lot of junk food thinking that this is like a treat
But then before that, we had white rice and before that we might had ramen for a snack
We would eat all day
we had ramen which is really junky,
we had white rice which is storing up my ass,
then we had junk food which is sugar and we don't even drink pop or anything
But if you drink orange juice, it's just sugar
all day long sugar sugar sugar
The last thing we tried to do is eject a little bit of exercise into our lives
because we just film stationary,
and then we sit in front of a computer and just edit in stationary position
so we're not burning anything
So we tried to inject a little bit of exercise into our lives
we did something called
SUPER EPIC DANCE PARTIES
in which it almost plays songs on everything we are doing
and dance uncontrollably for 5 minutes
It doesn't necessarily just dancing, we could do pushups, jumping jacks
fist fights
Fist pumping is very good as well
So we tried to do something a little more exercise
we don't have like a full exercise ....... , we don't go to the gym or anything
We just sing all the time
When we are in front of the computers, when our editing program is rendering
we would be like,
"I'm in the gym!"
"Just working on my fitness!!"
I enjoy our SUPER EPIC DANCE PARTIES
when we dance to PONG PONG THE PONG PONG SONG
I liked to dance to T-ara's Yayaya
I enjoy dancing to Honey Honey
I enjoy dancing to Fergilicious
(That's a good one)
And the last thing that we've done, we're talking about the lifestyle change
and we're replacing a lot of stuff that I cook with
Now I'm using coconut flour instead of white flour
I don't use white sugar anymore, I might use honey instead
or different like xylitol, source from coconut,
coconut oil and other nerdy stuff you don't wanna hear about
This has been proven to help us out of bail like I went from 217pounds
down to 184pounds now
I was like 172pounds and I'm now down to 150
Every morning when I go up on the scale goes up like
We still have a bit more that we want to get to
like tone up and firm up a bit
But we are on the right path, I think finally
We are looking to loos 5 more pounds
maybe 10 maximum and then that's it
Then I will be my original
ORIGINAL~~
Stop doing this motion because it means something nasty
What?!! What are you talking about?
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If you have a question for next TL;DR,
leave your question on the comment section below
Or check out the question that is already asked and you can thumb them up
in hopes to get our attention
If it doesn't get to our attention, we might choose something else anyways
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;Drs
where we talk about more stuff of our life in Korea
Take it away, Meemers...
She's asleep...
Sleeping kitten
Look how calm she's now before she surrender around and cause

title: How We Lost a Lot of Weight in Korea

Here in Portugal is very common to eat rice, except for breakfast. 
Everything in excess will make you gain fat. If you consume 3000 calories 
of fruit an veggies everyday and sit all day long you will eventually gain 
fat. It's much harder but you will. Find your middle ground and be happy. I 
for once couldn't live without rice. XD﻿

comments.text:
I live in a very low-populated state in the US in a low-populated city 
where everyone is either an artist or a hippy so pretty much everyone eats 
organic and raw food and most of my friends have never eaten at a McDonalds 
before so it's very strange to go to the more mainstream, "classic 
American" big cities where organic food culture isn't big and everyone eats 
junky food frequently.﻿
comments.author: Marissa Myers

comments.text: dont do it rice nuuuuu﻿
comments.author: dana

comments.text:
Diabetics are allowed 1/2 cup of carbs per meal.  That is a reasonable 
amount.﻿
comments.author: darian roscoe

comments.text:
The American Diabetes Association recommends ½ C. cooked pasta/beans/rice 
in a meal (measured after cooking). That would be under 30 carbs. I take my 
insulin. I am a type 2 that chose the insulin route because it is easier on 
the body (was taking Glipizide and Metformin). For bread and crackers, 
always check the total carbs on the box for the appropriate serving. Some 
corn tortillas allow for 3 per serving and others 1. Also keep in mind 
other sources of carbs such as green beans, corn, sugary squashes that 
contribute to the carbohydrate count. A diabetic may feel like eating more. 
Keep in mind, if you are eating more than ½ C carbs per meal, you should 
really talk to your doctor about reducing your meds because more than ½ C 
(or 30 carbs or less) is what is appropriate for a meal. We are spoiled by 
dishes like fried rice and sushi that have much more rice than allowed. 
Just because your meds allow you to eat more doesn't mean that you should. 
Finally, keep in mind that the body changes ALL carbohydrates to sugar, as 
that is what your body uses to keep you going. Before eating that extra ½ C 
rice or slice of bread, look on it as sugar added to the body.
comments.author: darian roscoe

comments.text:
+darian roscoe are you sure you mean 1/2 cup of carbs? not all foods 
contain the same amount of carbs so 1/2 cup of A could have more carbs in 
1/2 cup of B.

would imagine they may eat more as long as they take their medicin.

comments.text:
I don't know a lot of sign language, but I know that the movement that you 
both did at the end of the video means you are asking for ketchup. At least 
in French Canadian SL, that is. My uncle has a deaf brother, plus has a 
maintenance company that hires a lot of mutes so he's learned from there. 
So diet talking... I am pretty sure ketchup is not good for you guys. ;)

I've been eating a lot of rice, I would in fact not survive without my rice 
cooker at least three meals a week. I am not loosing weight so far, but I 
find rice less heavy and more filling than let's say pasta. Weight-wise, I 
know I am eating too much cheese. I need to cut on that but damn this is 
soooo hard!﻿

comments.text: sad but true ...
comments.author: lupina015

comments.text:
So glad you made this video. This is actually my biggest fear about living 
in Korea. A lot of people when they move to a new place often put on weight 
because they're eating different foods and leading a different lifestyle. 
My family hosted international students and we always sent them home a few 
kilos heavier from eating our kiwi food. I've spent the last year working 
hard to lose weight and don't want to ruin all my hard work. I want to 
enjoy the different food available in Korea but I'll try to balance it out 
by joining a gym. I'd love to know more about how gyms work in Korea so if 
you have since tried out a gym since making this video and find out more 
about it please make a video about it. ﻿
comments.author: genmusicofficial

comments.text:
You shouldn't need to join a gym, exercising in Korea is laughably easy 
(unless you wanna use weights). The parks have free exercise machines, and 
there's mountain trails EVERYWHERE. I mean 'just walk out of the house a 
few blocks and it's there' everywhere. It's also pretty safe at night, and 
depending on the area there's lots of people walking/running at night in 
the parks. Yeah there's lots of foods but the portions aren't crazy big 
(and you can share if they happen to be) you'll most likely walk 
everywhere, so as long as you don't pig out you should be ok.

This coming from an American who went there 3 months as holidays to Korea 
to visit a relative and I dropped the pounds like crazy (I did exercise a 
lot every day, because it was so easy and free to do). When I came back and 
met one of my friends, she actually got startled scared when I called out 
for her because she didn't know it was me.

comments.author: 1234kingconan

comments.text:
A few months ago, I thought carbohydrates were the problem. I went on a low 
carb diet, and it worked, I lost 10 kg. But I've also recently been doing a 
high carb low fat diet and that also works, I'm further losing weight and 
I'm also less puffy. Turns out a combination of carbs and fat makes me gain 
weight. So eliminating either one worked for me. Honestly, try a high carb 
low fat diet and see if it works for you. You still get to satisfy your 
sweet tooth by eating fruit.﻿
comments.author: MsWannabeGamer

comments.text:
+danL1011 it's 2015 and you're quoting one study from the 1950s? Cite the 
source, I'll read it up on my own. Study methodology and sample size matter 
too.
comments.author: doryfishie2

comments.text: +doryfishie2 It's not just math. Metabolism differs among people.
comments.author: 재기찡

comments.text:
+doryfishie2 [A surplus of calories causes weight gain.Whether they come 
from carb, fat or protein.]
Not true.  A study done in the fifties fed test subjects a 1000 calorie a 
day diet for a week -- three groups: one mostly carbs, one mostly protein, 
and one mostly fats.  Those on the carbs actually GAINED weight! 
 Apparently their metabolic rate slowed drastically.

As for joint pain, that was a common side effect of those on the Atkins 
diet who consumed too much protein instead of fat. The SAD probably 
contains too much protein.
comments.author: danL1011

comments.text:
+danL1011 The body burns carbs first and stores any excess carbs, fat and 
protein. A surplus of calories causes weight gain. Whether they come from 
carb, fat or protein. Basically, eat less than you burn. Puffiness is more 
likely to be due to water retention. Drink more water, consume less sodium. 
As long as you get adequate protein it really doesn't matter whether it's 
low carb or low fat. The only real standard across all diets is you need 
adequate protein. And a caloric deficit if your goal is fat loss. Assuming 
you're an average healthy person. I doubt anyone but bodybuilders eat that 
much protein to lead to joint pain anyway.
comments.author: doryfishie2

comments.text:
+재기찡 not true. if you want to lose weight: eat less than you burn. it 
doesn't matter if it's low carb or high carb, if you're at a caloric 
deficit you lose weight. it might not work for some people because they're 
simply not at a deficit. if you go high carb but reduce total food intake 
so you're at a deficit; you still lose weight without aerobic exercise. 
it's just math.
comments.author: doryfishie2

comments.text: +Aly Dood go fruit your self! 😉
comments.author: miss Holly

comments.text: +Aly Dood YASSSSS!!!! :D
comments.author: lupina015

comments.text: Fruit bats unite! 🍓🍊🍌🍐🍇
comments.author: Aly Dood

comments.text:
[Turns out a combination of carbs and fat makes me gain weight.] 
Absolutely true.  The body burns carbs first and stores any exceed carbs or 
fat.

[I'm also less puffy.]

That's probably due to excess protein when you were on the low carb diet. 
 Protein causes inflammation.  That's why people on Atkins reported joint 
pain and feeling "swollen".

If weight loss is your goal, a low carb/high fat/adequate protein diet is 
most effective.  Better for your health in general too since your blood 
sugar level is more stable.  Better for brain function too.  Absolutely 
superior if you are diabetic.

But I am glad you are doing well on a low fat/high carb diet even though I 
think the issue was protein which most Americans consume way too much of.
comments.author: danL1011

comments.text:
+재기찡 It did work for me and the only exercise I do is ride a bike for 30 
minutes a day to university and back. When I'm on vacation, I do no 
exercise whatsoever, but instead up my fruit intake and continue to lose 
weight.
comments.author: MsWannabeGamer

comments.text:
High carb diet involves a good amount of aerobic exercise as well. 
Otherwise it might not work for lots of people.

comments.author: Phresh Fm

comments.text:
Rice makes you fat? Carbs make you fat?????!


You guys must be soo retarded. The human body cells runs on glucose aka 
carbs aka sugar. Rice, noodles, potatoes n fruits doesn't make you fat, its 
what you put ontop of it. Oil, butter, dead flesh animals etc. Remember the 
fat you eat is the fat you wear.

If you wanna lose weight long term eat high carb low fat n low sodium! Its 
thats simple. No yoyo bull shit.

You guys need to understand human physiology n anatomy﻿
comments.author: DV Entertainment Channel

comments.text:
+KettiexD
I've tried a keto diet last year and hoooly crap (I usually go all the way, 
so I cut most sugar and carbs), I was dropping the pounds like crazy, and I 
didn't really change my (lack of) exercise routine, just walked a tiny bit 
at night. Also I didn't wake up with numb arms/hands, and wasn't having 
problems with sleep as much. Once I moved I didn't have the full access of 
a kitchen so I got fat, but that's about to change so I'm gonna try it 
again. (btw I did it mostly for health, not actual weight)
comments.author: yakurimoe

comments.text:
OMG would you all stop fucking arguing!  YOU ARE ALL RIGHT.  But it's

carbohydrates, fats, proteins and sugar and you fucking exercise!  Not 
fucking rocket science and all this fad diet shit is just that a fucking 
fad, next week will be something else.  There is no big secret to not being 
fat... it is called watching what you eat limit your fucking portions and 
move your fat ass... not really hard to do.  All of you shut the fuck up 
and stop arguing about something that is pointless you are all stupid.

Your fucking joking right!? Theres a MASSIVE difference between *simple*

dew every 2 hours to be perfectly healthy.

comments.text:
Think about it. If rice and noodles make you fat, how come majority of

comments.author: whatdoulike69

comments.text:
Hey guys! I was "no carbs" too at the beginning, but that s*cks. Why? 
Because every cell of our body needs carbs to function (not protein, and 
even less fat. Maybe some but just in little amounts). Did you ever notice 
that fruits or vegetables are PURE carbs :D? fruits = sugar. But sugar we 
need to live. Please check out the 80/10/10 diet or RawTill4 Diet! Carbs 
are good. Eat more carbs too loose weight, cut off animal products and fats 
and you will feel soooooooo good! I promise.
I know so many people outside there living this lifestyle, eating up to 
3000 calories a day, not working out like crazy or something (sometimes 
even no workouts) and being lean, healthy and happy!

(The diets I mentioned are mostly about raw foods. But thats really not 
necessary. You can perfectly eat only cooked meals all day long and have 
the same results)﻿
comments.author: Ines Li

i'm studying culinary arts and i eat food with high butter content for at 
least 3 days/week and i didn't sweat a bit since i moved to Sydney,

here and still didn't lose any weight. i even eat healthy food (i haven't 
eaten junk food for almost a year, i don't drink sodas and rarely eat 
processed food. i used to eat Mcdonalds, KFC, dominos and other junk food 
like crazy back in Indonesia and didn't gain any weight. can't wait to move 
back to indonesia to lose a lot of weight. thanks by the way

comments.author: gelica09

comments.text:
Most Asians have a high metabolism from many generations of eating rice in 
every meal which is high in carbohydrates.  Americans that have ancestors 
from Europe, Africa and South & North American natives have not eaten rice 
in multiple meals or everyday so their metabolism is not as fast. I am a 
mixed race black/white American and I was to eat rice with every meal I 
would gain weight very fast.  I don't have a high metabolism to burn it 
off. It's has to do with the hereditary genes and the region.  For example 
Natives from Alaska eat seal and whale meat that has brown fat.  Most 
Alaskans carry brown fat in their bodies to store for energy to keep body 
temperature normal and prevent hypothermia (freezing to death).  It's in 
their genes to have that ability since no one else can save brown fat in 
their bodies.
